author: Sarah Turner
title: Salem is America's spookiest city and the perfect place for a Halloween holiday
text:
As I checked in to the Salem Waterfront hotel, I saw a plastic skeleton lounging on the sofa. And the wifi password was ‘spooky’.
Head into town and dry ice ­whistles down the street. You can hear blood-curdling screams from surrounding buildings.
Go into the CVS pharmacy and you might find a solemn-faced Puritan eyeing up the detergents.
Outside, people accuse each other of being witches – and through it all, the town’s folk go about their business, nipping into Pamplemousse the deli for Vampire Blood wine. As you do. In Salem.
The New England town has long captured the imagination of horror writers and fans of scary movies, and on Halloween half a million people turn out.
Trick or treat: Halloween fun on the streets of Salem
Designer witches hats? No problem. Long flowing capes? Practically de rigueur. Love potions? Artemisia Botanicals will set you up – along with an artisanal broom.
Salem is possibly the only place on earth where looking like a goth will enhance your career prospects – legions are in place to entice you into the side shows.
Every night is party night in October. It’s dress-up central, led by an army of happy, sugared-up kids (most shops do trick or treating for the whole month).
All because, in 1692, a group of young girls accused some local men and women of being witches.
Hundreds were thrown in jail, 20 were killed. There’s a moving ­monument to them at Gallows Hill.
Pretty: The town's harbour
Next door is the cemetery where Judge John Hathorne, who presided over the trials, has his headstone.
After the hysteria ended, Salem tried hard to forget about it until Arthur Miller’s The Crucible revived interest in 1953 and (less cerebrally) the sitcom Bewitched, which was filmed here. Salem saw its popularity soar – there’s even a statue of Samantha.
There’s another side to Salem these days, as a wealthy small-town neighbour to Boston. Women hanging out together are probably convening for a trip to the Peabody, the oldest museum in the US.
It’s a spectre-free zone, mixing maritime ephemera with Chinese ceramics, and a brilliant introduction to the other side of Salem.
Hat trick: Kids have fun
After the witch hysteria, the Massachusetts town became one of New England’s biggest shipping points, bringing coffee and spices to the New World.
These days, the witty David Bowie (yes, really) is passionate about spices, with his shop near the port ( salemspice.com ).
According to my guide Karen Scalia, who gives fascinating foodie tours, Salem was home to the US’s first millionaire, who made his money from peppercorns.
And so to nightfall. Bewitched After Dark is run by Jeff – wry, funny and keener on historical facts than ghost tales.
And he says there were obviously never any witches in Salem.
Except over Halloween, of course.
Travel File Creepy crawl: Bewitched After Dark walks, $20. Must book. bewitchedafterdark.com
Salem Food Tours start from $20. salemfoodtours.com
Top Tip: The Boston Ferry to Salem is a great way to see the coast. ($25, 1hr) bostonharborcruises.com
Eat out: Nice vegan food at Flying Saucer, hearty $6.95 lunch at Red’s, fantastic seafood at Finz on the harbour, $30 a head. hipfinz.com
Book it: BA to Boston from £478. ba.com/ boston Doubles rooms at the Waterfront hotel from $92 salemwaterfronthotel.com
